instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
threads.message:
Got new touchbar with famous charge issue. 

I saw about CD3215C00 ( that chips brings current machine). 

Have checked with USB and see that all ports except one recieving 5V and 0,3 A. One port recieves 5V 0,15V. 

Is that cd3215C00 issue? I must change only one CD or all 4 ?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
threads.message:
Check resistance to ground around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips and compare values.
Post voltage for <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and F7000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
threads.message:
F7000 about 0.13V, <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 5V on all pins. 

About resistance to ground all are above 1 million except <RESISTOR>R2836</RESISTOR> 75K and some more about 100K but i guess it is ok?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
threads.message: Seems like <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is responsable for port that is reciving 0,15Amp, so if it is so i have to change all 4 components or just that one? I got wings with donor and have experience in changing smc, reballing etc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
threads.message: No if it is the bad one, only it has to be changed. Do a diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and and the LDO lines around each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> to see if one value is lower than all the others. If <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> has lower readings than the others, it's the one that is bad. But check those measurements first before replacing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
threads.message:
You must always check power rails on diode mode; red to ground first, but need to note value with black probe to ground too.
If get very low values, then switch to 200 ohm scale...
Compare the values on the 4 chips on similar lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
threads.message: Solved. It was <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. Thanks to everyone

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging
